Value: From hot to cold spots: climate change will modify endemism centers of small mammals in a biodiversity hotspot

Gabriela Alves-Ferreira; Flavio Mariano Machado Mota; Carolina Bello; Maurício Humberto Vancine; Thadeu Sobral-Souza; Alexandre R. Percequillo; Thomas E. Lacher Jr; Mauro Galetti; Ricardo S. Bovendorp
Baseline: (1970-2000) and two future climate scenarios: 2050 (2041-2060) and 2070 (2061-2080)
literature from Bovendorp et al. (2017b); online platforms GBIF (gbif.org) and speciesLink (specieslink.net)

We used Ecological Niche Models (ENMs) through an ensemble approach to assess the potential distribution of 44 species of small mammals (Rodentia and Marsupialia) using baseline (1970-2000) and future (2050 and 2070) climate scenarios. We evaluate if protected areas and forest remnants in the Atlantic Forest of South America (AF) will ensure the taxonomic diversity (TD) and phylogenetic diversity (PD) of non-volant small mammals under scenarios of future climate change

• Occurrence records are accurate and representative.
• Species are at equilibrium with their environment.
• The niche is preserved over time.
• Models do not consider potential for adaptation to climate change.
• Species have unlimited dispersal capacity.
maxent; glm; mars; randomForest; suport vector machines; maxlike
We created ensemble models with “weighted averages” through  the TSS value (Ribeiro-Souza et al., 2022) using the R package sdm (Naimi and Araújo, 2016).

We used the algorithms MARS, Support Vector Machines - SVM, MaxEnt, Random forest, MaxLike, and Generalized Linear Models - GLM with default parameters to build the ENMs using the R packages dismo (Hijmans et al., 2011) and sdm (Naimi and Araújo 2016). We calibrated and evaluated the models using the R packages dplyr (Wickham et al., 2023), raster (Hijmans and Etten, 2012) and dismo (Hijmans et al., 2011). First, we divided the occurrence records for test (30%) and training (70%) (Ribeiro-Souza et al., 2022) 20 times for each algorithm to calibrate the models. Then we used a weighted averaging based on TSS statistics and Area Under Curve (AUC) to evaluate them. To create a single model for each species and climate scenario we used only the models that present AUC and TSS values greater than the average of all algorithms. After that, we created ensemble models with “weighted averages” through  the TSS value (Ribeiro-Souza et al., 2022) using the R package sdm (Naimi and Araújo, 2016). This method provides a consensus distribution area and defines areas with high uncertainty (Araújo and New, 2007). Lastly, we transformed the final continuous models into binary (presence = 1 and absence = 0) using the threshold that maximizes the sum of sensitivity and specificity (Max SSS) (Liu et al., 2013).

R 4.3.1 
R Packages used include dismo (Hijmans et al., 2011), sdm (Naimi and Araújo 2016), dplyr (Wickham et al., 2023), and raster (Hijmans and Etten, 2012).
The taxon names can be accessed in the supplementary table S1.

We focus on terrestrial small mammals and recognize around 30 species of marsupials (Didelphidae) and 97 species of small rodents (Caviidae, Cricetidae, Ctenomyidae, Echimyidae) (Bovendorp et al., 2017b; Abreu et al., 2022)

We checked the occurrences to eliminate inconsistencies, such as duplicates and those outside the known distribution of the species. All occurrences are double-checked by a specialist in small mammals of the region.
We divided the occurrence records for test (30%) and training (70%) (Ribeiro-Souza et al., 2022) and rerun the partition 20 times for each algorithm to calibrate the models.

We selected five bioclimatic variables with the Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) less than 2.0 (Dormann et al., 2013): Mean Diurnal Range (Mean of monthly (max temp - min temp)) (BIO2), Mean Temperature of Wettest Quarter (BIO08), Mean Temperature of Driest Quarter (BIO9), Precipitation of Wettest Month (BIO13), and Precipitation of Coldest Quarter (BIO19).
We used data from baseline period (1970-2000).

We used two Global Circulation Models (GCM): Model for Interdisciplinary Research on Climate version 6 (MIROC6) and the Canadian Earth System Model version 5 (CanESM5) (Collins et al., 2011; Navarro-Racines et al., 2020). For each future scenario, we considered two Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) representing optimistic (SSP370) and pessimistic (SSP585) greenhouse gas scenarios.
We selected five bioclimatic variables with the Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) less than 2.0 (Dormann et al., 2013).
We used the Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) less than 2.0 (Dormann et al., 2013) to choose the least correlated variables.
